finish_revert_migration already includes context as a parameter,

re-generate the context inside finish_revert_migration, we should

an optional parameter for this method. We should always pass a
context down because it might be needed somewhere inside

subject: Limit changed partitions when rebalancing
commit_message:
Limit changed partitions when rebalancing

When adding new regions or zones to an existing, already balanced
ring it is very likely that 100% of the partitions will be rebalanced
at once. This will create a lot of replication traffic in the backend
network and might have a performance impact.

This patch adds a new option to the rebalance command to limit the
number of partitions that will be reassigned. This is done by limiting
the number of partitions that are choosen for a reassignment.

Failed devices are not considered when applying the limit, thus a
rebalance with a limit might actual change more partitions if required.

The existing behavior and command line options are not modified. To
rebalance the whole ring one can execute the rebalance multiple times.
The following example limits the number of reassigned partitions to 100
(and ignores the initial value for the seed argument):

    swift-ring-builder object.builder rebalance --reassign-max 100

Two unit tests have been added to ensure the correct behavior when adding
a new region to an existing, already balanced ring and dealing correctly
with failed devices.

Closes-Bug: 1367826
Also-By: Florent Flament <florent.flament-ext@cloudwatt.com>
Change-Id: I36e4bb69c9238d44b861e1cd05a26977a9852140

subject: swiftclient should check response before upload
commit_message:
swiftclient should check response before upload

Scenario:

1. swiftclient receives a request to upload an image
2. swiftclient obtains an auth token
3. upload of the image commences are multiple chunks.
4. mid way the orignal auth token expires.
5. swiftclient attempts to upload the next chunk with the same auth token
6. Upload fails with a 401 after attempting to upload the entire chunk.

Proposed solution:

1. Fire a HEAD call before the actual PUT call with the same headers.
2. If the status returned is a 401, refetch the auth token and retry.
3. Upload the remaining chunks with the new token.

Fixes bug #1298283

subject: Fix filter rule of hypervisor-servers search api
commit_message:
Fix filter rule of hypervisor-servers search api

The response of hypervisor search APIs:
- /v2/{tenant_i}d/os-hypervisors/{hypervisor_hostname}/servers
- /v2/{tenant_i}d/os-hypervisors/{hypervisor_hostname}/search
- /v3/os-hypervisors/search?query={hypervisor_hostname}
are only support partial match search, not support exact match.
Therefore the result of `nova hypervisor-servers {hostname}`
can include untargeted hypervisor servers.

ex. There are 2 servers exist, test1 and test10. The command
result of `nova hypervisor-servers test1` includes both servers.

The cause is the filter rule of sqlalchemy that is filtered by
the wildcard of hypervisor_hostname, as `%hostname%`.

This patch will enable to search servers by not only partial search
but also exact match of the target hypervisor. The user may trigger
a partial search by including the % character, url-encoded, in the
API call, such as: "/v3/os-hypervisors/search?query=fake%25"

Add swift-ring element

A swift-ring element consists of the basic swift package and the
swift-ring-builder tool. The purpose of this element is exclusively to create
and update swift ring files. The benefit here is that it may be used on an
undercloud or overcloud controller node without having to install the entire

generate swift rings on the node in question (as well as other things) so right
now any node with the swift element must be a part of the swift rings.

subject: Use HTTP headers to count bytes in middleware
commit_message:
Use HTTP headers to count bytes in middleware

The bug at https://bugs.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+bug/1337761
reports that swift performance is unacceptably degraded when
swift_middleware is turned on to publish samples.

There are two possible reasons for why this may be happening:

* publishing samples is itself too slow/expensive
* measuring the size of request and response bodies is too slow

The patchset attempts to provide a proof of a concept for addressing
the second by using, when available, the content-length header in
requests and responses and _not_ measuring the size of responses
when no content-lenght is provided by the proxied server.

The existence of this code should allow for further comparative
testing with swift-bench to see what ought to happen to resolve the
performance difficulties. Casual testing shows that counting the
size of data is less of a contributing factor than publishing
samples.

Not that at this time swift is generally good at returning
content-length headers when requesting an object from the store (as
content-length exists as a piece of object metadata), but less good
when other requests are made. Presumably this is not a huge problem
as the metrics are primarily oriented towards measuring the passage
of objects over the proxy interface and the size of those objects
will vastly outstrip other responses.

If it is a problem it is quite likely that there is some way to fall
back to the original code (which iterated over the response body to
count its bytes)[1] or to improve swift itself to be better at
providing length headers where possible.

Generally speaking it makes sense that using header values that have
already been calculated is going to be a win over iterating bodies.
If iterating bodies is the only way to calculate the cost then it
is probably best, as said in the comments on the bug report, to do
that iteration within swift itself where the cost can be minimized,
not a piece of middleware.

Note, too, that these tests are quite crufty. Using something like
wsgi-intercept[2] to model actual web requests would probably be
mode comprehensible. Again I didn't want to make that change here as
it would obscure the point of this patch.

[1] That's not present in this code because a) it hid the purpose of
the change too much b) generators make it hard to do cleanly.

[2] http://wsgi-intercept.readthedocs.org/en/latest/

Related-Bug: #1337761

Change-Id: I0cbd40105b1f07a9775a9fc42bde50c233f0b950

subject: Treat 404s as 204 on object delete in proxy
commit_message:
Treat 404s as 204 on object delete in proxy

This change adds an optional overrides map to _make_request method
in the base Controller class.

  def make_requests(self, req, ring, part, method, path, headers,
                    query_string='', overrides=None)

Which will be passed on the the best_response method. If set and
no quorum it reached, the override map is used to attempt to find
quorum.

The overrides map is in the form:

    { <response>: <override response>, .. }

The ObjectController, in the DELETE method now passes an override map
to make_requests method in the base Controller class in the form of:

    { 404: 204 }

Statuses/responses that have been overridden are used in calculation
of the quorum but never returned to the user. They are replaced by:

    (STATUS, '', '', '')

And left out of the search for best response.

Change-Id: Ibf969eac3a09d67668d5275e808ed626152dd7eb
Closes-Bug: 1318375
